content: Top 10 Myths About Common Law Marriage

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td div div div table tbody tr td em b span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div table tbody tr td em b a span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div table tbody tr td font span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span p span
content: Believe it or not, the concept of "Common Law Marriage" is still alive and kicking in the State of Colorado! The fact is, many people are tripped up when the legal ramifications of this relic in the law rears its ugly head. Here are the "Top 10 Myths About Common Law Marriage":

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span p b span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span p span
content: : If I am married by common law, it wonÂ’t affect my legal rights after a break-up, right?

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span blockquote b span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span blockquote span
content: . You could be subjected to the same claims for property division or maintenance (alimony), as you would face in a traditional divorce.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span p b span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span p span
content: : I can't be common law married unless I have been cohabitating for 10 years, right?

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span blockquote b span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span blockquote span
content: . There is no set time period under Colorado law to be declared common law married.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span p b span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span p span
content: : It doesn't matter if my friends and family think I am married, so long as I know the truth, right?

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span blockquote b span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span blockquote span
content: . In a legal dispute, count on your "ex" to claim otherwise and get all of his/her buddies to support that claim, especially if there is money involved. The key is whether you "hold yourself out" as married, and that vague term can get pretty expensive to legally prove, one way or the other.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span p b span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span p span
content: : If I have children with my significant other, I am automatically common law married, right?

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span blockquote b span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span blockquote span
content: . Not necessarily. The key is whether you hold yourself out as "husband" and "wife".

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span p b span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span p span
content: : I told my insurance carrier that I am married so my boyfriend/girlfriend can get benefits. This isolated action can't hurt me, right?

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span blockquote b span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span blockquote span
content: . Any public declarations you make about your marital status can come back and hurt you later.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span p b span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span p span
content: : So what if I am considered common law married, I can simply "annul" the marriage, right?

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span blockquote b span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span blockquote span
content: . If you are held to be common law married, you will have to go through a full-blown dissolution of marriage proceeding.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span p b span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span p span
content: : I can't be common law married unless I have plans to go through with the ceremony, right?

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span blockquote b span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span blockquote span
content: . You may be considered common law married even if you and your significant other have never even considered "taking the plunge" publicly.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span p b span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span p span
content: : So what if I filed a joint tax return, that is a federal issue, and it can't be used against me in a state court, right?

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span blockquote b span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span blockquote span
content: . It can and almost definitely will be used against you by your ex's lawyer.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span p b span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span p span
content: : As long as my relationship with my ex-boyfriend/girlfriend stays strong, common law marriage doesn't matter to me, right?

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span blockquote b span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span blockquote span
content: . If you die unexpectedly, your significant other may be entitled to inherit your assets, potentially depriving your biological heirs of a lot of money.

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span p b span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span p span
content: : Okay, so maybe I have a common law situation. I shouldn't have to worry about this unless my relationship is about to end, right?

tag: html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span blockquote b span
html body text div table tbody tr td div div div span blockquote span
content: . You should be as informed as possible about your rights, as there are almost always steps you can take to protect yourself. Be informed, be cautious, and be proactive!
